I think it's a bit of a novelty, to be honest. I mean, it's great that they're out there trying, but let's be real, they're just not on the same level as able-bodied athletes. I've seen some of these disabled athletes competing, and it's just not the same. The speed, the strength, the agility - it's all compromised. And don't even get me started on the equipment they use. It's like they're getting an unfair advantage or something.

I'm not saying they shouldn't be allowed to participate or anything, but I think they should have their own separate competitions. You know, like the Paralympics or something. And another thing, I think it's a bit of a distraction. I mean, the crowd's attention is taken away from the "real" athletes, you know, the ones who are actually capable of performing at a high level. It's like, I get it, we want to be inclusive and all that, but at the end of the day, it's about the sport, not about making everyone feel good about themselves.

I've seen some of these disabled athletes getting all sorts of attention and accolades, and it's just not deserved, in my opinion. I mean, yeah, that's all well and good, but at the end of the day, it's about winning, not about feeling good about yourself.

So, yeah, that's my take on it. Disabled athletes are fine, I guess, but they're just not on the same level as the rest of us.
